question.text: The oxidation states of iron atoms in compounds <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></mfenced></math>, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></mfenced></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mfenced></math>, respectively, are <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">y</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">z</mi></math>. Then sum of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">y</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">z</mi></math> is ........... <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><munder><mrow><msub><mi>Na</mi><mn>4</mn></msub><mfenced open="[" close="]"><mrow><mi>Fe</mi><msub><mfenced><mi>CN</mi></mfenced><mn>5</mn></msub><mfenced><mi>NOS</mi></mfenced></mrow></mfenced></mrow><mfenced><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></mfenced></munder><mtext> </mtext><munder><mrow><msub><mi>Na</mi><mn>4</mn></msub><mfenced open="[" close="]"><msub><mi>FeO</mi><mn>4</mn></msub></mfenced></mrow><mfenced><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></mfenced></munder><mtext> </mtext><munder><mfenced open="[" close="]"><mrow><msub><mi>Fe</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mfenced><mi>CO</mi></mfenced><mn>9</mn></msub></mrow></mfenced><mfenced><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mfenced></munder></math>

solution.text:
Oxidation state of Fe in Na4FeCN5NOS:

Charge of CN =-1

Charge of NOS=-1

Suppose oxidation state of Fe = x

4+x-5-1=0⇒x=+2

Oxidation state of Fe in Na4FeO4:

4+x-8=0⇒x=+4

Oxidation state of Fe in Fe2CO9 =0 because carbonyl is neutral ligand.

The oxidation states of iron in these compounds will be

A = +2   B = +4   C = 0 

The sum of oxidation states will be = 6.
